content: time method for small circumference knitting but knit most of the hat bor beginning of round on 1 16 us 5 circular choose your circular length chart key based on your preferred small circumference construction another note- i am a very loose knitter this hat has to be a little more snug because it has a folded brim and not a rib notions stitch marker scissors tapestry needle gauge colorwork and stockinette 3 5mm 20 stitches and 26 row = 4 10cm please swatch in the round for this pattern 3 directions beginning with 3 55mm needles and mc cast on 90 100 110 sts with a provisional cast on join in the round being careful not to twist your stitches and pm to indicate bor provisional cast on is my favorite hack for an easy folded brim if you opt for a different cast on make sure it isn t too tight so you can still fold comfortably folded brim rounds 1- 11 12 13 in mc k to end round 12 13 14 in mc p to end move to working the chart for your size working chart work following chart for 11 12 13 rounds you will have 5 chart repeats when you reach the round 12 13 14 you will fold your brim fold brim so that wrong sides are together and following the chart for round 12 13 14 knit each stitch together with its counterpart on the cast-on edge be careful to align your stitches correctly here and check as you progress so that you are not twisting the brim continue working your chart to the end final round with cc k2tog across the round cut your yarn and use a tapestry needle to thread the tail through the remaining stitches pull tight and weave in the end securely it is important to make sure you have an even gauge across your fold round so that when you do not end up with a visible seam in your hat finishing weave in all ends and block gently congrats on finishing and i hope you enjoyed this pattern and that you see some milkweed beetles this summer 4 charts size 1 size 2 size 3 5 a note from the leafhopper thank you so very much for knitting this pattern i hope it was as fun for you to knit as it was for me to design a huge thank you to ritual dyes for providing yarn support to this project and supporting entomological education to stay in the
